p: Seventh, reducing high alcohol intake. This March, various people died after drinking industrial-strength alcohol, based on a false belief that it would protect them from COVID-19. Inversely, associations with heavy alcohol drinking and adverse infection outcome have been reported throughout history. Epidemiological studies found associations between alcohol abuse and viral infections, including HIV-AIDS [ 37], hepatitis C [ 38], and community-acquired pneumonia [ 39]. Excess alcohol disrupts adaptive immunity by affecting T lymphocytes balance, T-cell functioning, and peripheral B cells [ 40]. Reducing high alcohol intake may be favourable for COVID-19 susceptibility and outcomes. In line with the World Health Organization guidelines, it is recommended that alcohol intake should be eliminated or only be consumed in moderation. Also, those who do not drink alcohol should not start drinking [ 41].
